TRANSCRIPT OF 196th REGULAR MEETIID OF EXECUTIVE DIRECTORS HElJ) IN THE BOARD ROOM ON TUESDAY, OCTOBER 25, 1949 at 10:00 a.m.
CHAIRMAN: Will the meeting please come to order. (Garner) This is our first trial of this new seating arrangement. I trust that it
will prove to be satisfactory. We \'Till try it a few weeks and see.
TANSLEY: There appears to be more room.
CHAIRMAN: The first item is approval of the minutes of the 19Sth meeting. You have
had the minutes. Are there any comments or corrections? If not, they will
stand approved.
The Treasurer's Department, working with the Committee on Foreign Banking, representing leading commercial banks in the United states, has worked out
an arrangement regarding the issue of agreements on letters or credit in
connection with our loan disbursements. You have had a copy of this procedure and a draft resolution. Are there any questions regarding it?
HOPPENOl': I am quite agreeable to that paper. There is only one question I wanted
to ask. Would it be possible - I do not see any precise case where it
should be done now - lfOuld it be possible to extenl that same procedure
of letters of credit to people who sell the material themselves? Suppose, for instance, that the borrower has a very large amount to buy from a
particular business, would it be possible for the Bank to give this same
guarantee to this firm? The people who furnish that material may have
credi t of tileir own but do not want to go to the bank and can ask the
International Bank to extern to them the same kind of credit; would that
be possible? ,)WERS: Yes, it is perfectly possible and I believe in one or two cases the
Treasurer's Department has worked out such an arrangement. We have not
had many requests for it. I think Mr. Crena de Iongh would k:now more about that. - 2242 -  2.
r 'NA DE ~ONGH: I do not see any objections, Mr. Chairman. Of cour?e, the request has to come from the borrower. In case of guarantees, I do not see any objections. In case of cash collateral, there might be a question whether the borrower
wanted to make a deposit not with a bank but with private individuals.
However, I think if the borrower would think the recipient would be
creditworthy, I do not see why this system should not work just as well for
a bank as well as for a business firm or an industry.
CHAIRMAN: You were t~ng about guarantees, not depositing cash?
HOPPENOT : No, no, guarantees.
CHAIRMAN: Vie could do that.
Are there any other questions? TANSLEY: I would certainly agree and express same surprise that up to now it has
been necessary to deposit collateral. CRENA DE IONGH: I do not understand. GARNER: Mr. Tansley expresses surprise we had to deposit collateral. CRENA DE The collateral procedure was worked out at the time with the banks. Only IONGH: in the case of the Finnish Loan where we felt it might be cheaper and better
we took the initiative to introduce the system of guaranties. SOWERS: We might add that under the commitment charge policy, before it was changed,
it did not make the same difference to our borrowers that it does now. CHAIRMAN: No further questions? Do I hear a motion? (Moved and Second.ed) All in
favor, please Bay II Aye". Contrary mi.n:led, "No". It is so ordered. It has seemed to us that it would be useful for the information of the
Directors to ask the Treasurer to outline briefly the procedure followed
in cormection with end-use supervision of our loans. In general, you know
the procedure, but we thought it would be helpful to have him give a little
more specific description of just how the Bank operates.
- 2243 - CRENA DE IONGH: Mr. Chairman, I think I should start by pointing out that the procedure of
our end-use supervision for the general purpose loans is rather different
from the procedure we follow in the project loans. In the general purpose
loans, we check on the disbursements, whether they tally with the program,
and then follow through the goods until they came into the country, and
whether they were used for the purposes we expected. The disbursements,
as you know, of all the general purposes loans are canpleted with a small
exception for Luxembourg. The end-use supervision is completed in France
am Hollani, ani in the Danish case J i t will be completed we think, around
:March of next year. I do not think I need to elaborate on this point any
more.
How the end-use supervision of the project loans is more complicated. It
is the purpose of the Bank not only to see to it that, as in the general
purpose loans, goods actually arrive in the country, but that the project
is completed. The Bank wants to know that when our money has been disbursed
and the goods have arrived, the project is executed as antiCipated. It is
clear that the Bank is not only interested in the use of specific goods it
finances, but in the whole project in itself, ani, therefore, in many cases,
in the availability of local currency for the completion of the project.
In many cases, the aoount of local currency is much bigger than the amount
of foreign exchange which the Bank provides; therefore, we had to follow
through the use of the local currency also and see that the local currency
is actually available. Of course, we cannot demand that all the local
currency a project requires (as in the Brazilian Traction case, up to five
years) will be available the moment the loan is signed, but we have to be
sure that the local currency is forthcoming, either from the budget of a
country or from "the income of a company. The Treasurerts Department checks
on all these things through accounting and engineering procedures. Before
a loan is signed, we ask the prospective borrowers whether they can furnish
_ ??I.1. _ rBENA DE IONGH: us with what is called Progress Reports; we have to follow through at the ,Cont Id) moment we are certain part of the project should be completed, that it
actually has been completed. An engineer has been attached to the Treasurer1s
staff, and is already working on these projects.
We have a number of signed loans on which As yet nothing has been disbursed.
These are the two loans to India, the loan to Colombia, the loan to the
Herstelbank ani the loan to Finland, am both the timber loans to Finlam.
and Yugoslavia. We have been in contact wi th all these countries, ani I
think that their progress reports will be coming forth regularly. We have
a number of active project loans such as in Brazil; the Brazi~ian Traction
Company furnishes us with their reports. We are following through on the
telephone system, on the electrical transmission system and in the
construction for hydro-electric power. Of course, in such big projects,
nothing runs exactly to schedule. If an official of the company comes to
us ani asks for changes, we discuss them with the Loan Department, and i f
the changes are not very important ani do not deviate from the project as
such, then we of course agree. Sometimes there are some delays in the
program as scbeduled, but up to now, the BraziJ.,ian Traction business BeemB
to b,e going well~ although there are signs that a local currency problem
may arise. In the Chilean Agricultural Machinery project, we are following
through on the sale of the agricultural machinery, the counter value of which
will be deposited in the balances of the Fomento. Up to now, the amount
forthcoming has not been the total value of the agricultural machinery,
because part of it was sold on credit. However, we are getting regular
reports. We are rather concerned about the local currency methods in
Chile. It is probable that one of the staff members of the Loan Department,
and I think one of my men will go to Chile to look into the question because
the reports are not coming in as regularly as expected, although we have
- 2245 - CRENA DE IONGH: reports which cover periods up to May, and some of them up to September of (Cont'd) this year.
As to Mexico, Mr. Chairman, the Board knows that Mr. Iliff is in Mexico at
present to discuss local currency problems which have arisen during this
first period of supervision.
With regard to Belgium, we have three projects there, the Linalux Project,
the Ferblatil Project and the Ougree-Marihaye Project. We get very
satisfactory Progress Reports, and the works are being executed on schedule,
although in the case of the Ferblatil Project the company has not all the
local exchange necessary at present am is emeavouring - and I think they
will succeed - to get the local exchange necessary to complete the project.
I think Mr. Chairman, that that is all I have to say, but I shall be very
glad to elaborate furtrer on al'\V point i f anyone desires.
CHAIRMAN: I think that is a good report of our procedure_ Are there any questions?
I would like to ask a few questions, or rather give examples, of what is
in IllY" mind. Taking as a basis three or four contracts; the first Dutch
country shipping loan provides for a number of datas which we find in
Schedule B am in Article VIII; it is said that the borrower shall furnish
the Bank with statements of the earnings of the sBips. Thus, from the general
shipping point of view, have you any idea of how the ships are paying their
way and are able to make profits to cover the loan? Do you feel that the
general shipping situation is changing and that trouble may be expected in
earning money on these ships?
CRENA DE Up to now, the voyage results of the ships have been quite satisfactory. IONGHs They have lived up to expectations.
HOPPENCYr: Another question I would ask, which may lead the Bank to know better on
future agricultural projects. Can you tell us what is the way of lending
or selling the agricultural material by Fomento to the farmers? What are
the terms of the instalments?
- 2246 -  b.
CRENA DE IONGH: I would not be able to say exactly for what periods of credit the goods are
sold; they are sold mostly on instalments, am that is why the amount that has been paid to Fomento has not reached the total value of the machinery.
. HOPPENar: But for general information, we do not know what kind of contract is best
between Fomento am the fanoors. Would tile fanners have to pay over two
or tllree or four years? Also what is the rate of interest?
CRENA DE IONGH: I am sorry that I do not know that figure by heart.
CHAIRMAN: But we do know it in tile Bank.
CRENA DE IONGH: Yes, we get reports of the amounts.
HOPPENar: 'A further very minor question; in the Brazilian loan, till actual breakdown
of money to be spent on the different parts of the project is not given,
it is said that the goods which could be paid out of the project of the
loan shall be agreed upon from time to time in writing; is that procedure
being done? For instance, is Brazil still telling the Bank that on the
first 25 million of the loan, so much is earmarked for telephones, so much
for electricity, or have they allocated the whole proceeds of the loan? CRENA DE We split up every loan into various categories of goods to make sure that IONGH: the whole amount will not prove to be insufficient which might happen if
one category would be excee~ed and too little would remain for another
category. We have split up the Brazilian Traction loan into three parts,
telephone, transmission, and electricity projects, but each part in itself
is split up again into categories and when Brazilian Traction comes to us
to make disbursements, we check with a rather detailed list to see that
every item comes in the right category. Is that what you mean?
HOPPENaI': Yes. It is the same with the Indian railway loan, the description of the
project is extreJQ:ely summary; I know that in fact tile papers which were
circulated to the Board gave very detailed picture of how money was to be
spent, but in the contract there is no breakdown. Will the Indian Government
- 2247 -  ( . HOPPENar : give the Bank such a breakdown, partial or whole, or have they already done (~ontld) so.
CRENA DE Yes. We do not make any disbursements before we have the full breakdown IONGH: and we already possess information from the Indian Government in the case
of the railway project.
BRESCIANI: I feel that the answer to the question I shall put now is perhaps already
included in your report, and in this case I apologize; it escaped my
attention. I mean the problem of local currency. As far as I see, there
are two kinds of local currency, first, counterpart of loans granted by
the Bank in foreign currency. For instance, the Bank grants t.o Italy a
loan of $10 million. The goods will be sold to the Italian producers
and manufacturers aOO so the Italian Goverrunent will get the counterpart
in local currency, that is to say, little more, at thB present exchange rate,
than 6 billion lira. My fi rst question is, does the Bank supervise the
use of these counterpart funds in the same way as E.C.A. does, as concerns
the counterpart of funds of the Marshall Aid. Does the Bank indicate to
local Governments the use of these funds1 Does it from time to time
release funds for special purposes1
The second question: counterpart funds generally will be not sufficient to
furnish the necessary local currency to complete the expenses for the
project. Does the Bank also extend its enquiries to the seconi kind of
the local currency? Does the Bank enquire into the amount of savings,
the probable development of savings in future years and so on? More
especially am I interested to know what the Bank is doing with the counter-
part, and whether there is a control or not. CRENA DE You are perfectly right in saying that the function of the local currency IomHz is in one case very different from the other one. What I pointed out was
that the country has to furnish local currency to complete the project.
We, therefore, have to make very sure when we sign the loan contract, that
- 2248 -  o.
CRENA DE TONGH: it can be expected that local currency will be forthcoming from the economy mttd) of the country; from savings may be, by issuing bonds, or by paying it
themselves; the object being to complete the project. I think that is
clear?
BRESCIANI: Yes.
CRENA DE The other local currency counterpart funds is a very different question. IONGH: That local currency is created out of the sale of goods which the Bank
imports. You will have noticed from the contracts that this happens only
in two cases, in the Chilean loan where we sell agricultural machinery, and
it will also be the case in the Colombian loan. The Treasurer I s Office
checks on the payments on the basis of the conditions of the loan. I
think the policy of counterpart funds is a very different matter, and I
would rather ask you to direct your question to the Chairman on that point.
The Treasurer's Office checks on these things, and I think the discussion
of the policy of the counterpart funds is a very difficult matter, and
varies in aspect in each specific loan. Up to now, we have not met this
problem very much. Of course, you will understand that in a project such
as Brazilian Traction, it does not arise at all as the imported machinery
is used by the borrower himself. It certainly arises in the case of
E.C.A.where imported COllSUJOOr goods are sold by respective governments;
in the E.C.A. case, therefore, they playa great part in the total econollJ3"
of a country. In the Bank's case that part is limited. In my opinion the
local currencies created by counterpart funds will also be more limited.
As the handling of the principle of local currency is a ma..tter of policy,
I think it should be discussed by the vanagement and not by me.
CHAIRMAN: },lay I say on this point that up to now we have not put specifically in the
contract the specified control on any counterpart funds, but I think that
occasions may well arise in which it would be desirable.
- 2249 - TANSLEY: Mr. Chairman, my question is, I think, rather akin to the one we have just
heard. Y/e are talking about raising of local currency and I thought that
more than once recently we have been told it has been difficult to raise
the local currency. The Mexlight one is the outstanding one. You have
touched on one or two more, the Belgian an::!. the Chilean. Is that because
it was just over-optimism on the part of the borrower at the time the
loan was taken or a rather over-optimistic assessment on the part of the
Bank? I would be interested in arwthing you can say bearing on this.
CRENA DE Well, I did not say so. It is always a difficult thing. In the Belgian IONGH: case, I just mentioned it because it shows how the money market for bonds
plays a role in this matter. As local currency becomes more and more a
matter of great importance the studies which the Bank will make on its
loan applications will certainly always have to be directed very specifically
to the question: can a country be expected to raise sufficient local
currency or not?
CHAIRMAN: I think we might say in the Chilean case there was not any over-optimism.
A good part of the local currency funds have to come out of the budget
and what concerns us a little bit is that we have not received specific
information that next year's budget will provide adequate funds. I think
our concern is to be sure that, and that is what we want to press, is that
when the budget is. prepared it will guarantee the necessary funds agreed
upon. They have been seanewhat delinquent in keeping us informed. I think
it is a similar situation in Mexico. The next year' e budget is being
prepared an::!. we have been asking specifically to be informed as to the
estimates of local currency expenditures for next year and assurances that
they will be included.
Of course, in these construction projects, at the time we make a loan,
it is sanetimes difficult to estimate how mueh will be required in anyone
period and, in some cases, the construction may be pushed fOl"'W8.rd a little
- 2250 -  .LV.
CHAIRlIAN: faster than estimated and they may run short. On the other hand, there '~ontld) may be delays in construction. I do not think there is any miscalculation
over all, but how to have funds when needed is a problem. We have to keep on top of that problem and there is no danger that the borrowers cannot
meet the bills.
TAliSLEY: Mr. Chairman, it was the Mexlight loan which bothered me the most in this
particular connection. For instance, at the last meeting the Loan Director
was more or less compelled to tell us that only part of the necessary local
currency would be appropriated from the budget and the rest would have to
be raised by a bond issue which would amost certainly have to be taken up
by the Central Bank.
BARANSKIl I lI'ould like to come back to counterpart fund control. When we have
discussed the Belgian Loan we have been informed that the Bank, generally
speaking, does not make the counterpart fund control. But just after that
I read in press release that in the case of the Chilean loan for the
agricultural project a release of the local currency counterpart funds
by the Bank was made. Was that a mistake in the information or really
something like that has happened?
CHAIRMAN: Can youconrnent on that, Mr. Crena de Iongh?
BARANSKI: I read in the press release that one Chilean paper mentioned that the Bank
released a part ofÂ· the local currency counterpart of the loan.
CHAIRMAN: Can any member of the staff give any information on that? Could lI'e get
that press release?
HOAR: What date was that?
BARANSKI: It was just after the Belgian Loan. That press information just seemed to
be inconsistent with the information we have got during the discussion on
the Belgian Loan.
HOAR: Press release on the Belgian Loan?
BARANSKI I Not a press release, the press digest of the Bank. The press digest
- 2251 -  L1.
BARANSKI: mentioned information given by a Chilean paper which says that the mttd) International Bank has released local currency counterpart for the general use of the Chilean budget.
. BEYEN: Mr. Chairman, is there not some misunderstanding'!
CHAIRMAN: We did not make a~ release.
BEYEN: I would like to say something on what Professor Bresciani said and then I
would like to come back on the question raised by Dr. Baranski.
First of all, I YlQuld like to point out that the E.C.A. position is entirely
different from ours because an operation of E.C.A. creates amounts of
counterpart local currencies of such magnitude that the whole monetary
position of the country is influenced. It is quite clear, not only because
of the magnitude of the funds but also because of the interest of E.C.A.
in the general monetary policy of til e country, that the local counterpart
of E.C.A. grants am loans should be controlled some way or other because
it might otherwise defeat the whole object of E.C.A. by giving a country
freedom of following monetary poliCies which it otherwise could not afford. In our case the counterpart problem arises only in connection with certain
goods bought with our loan in the case that those goods are 8 old on by the
borrower. If the borrower keeps the goods and uses them, questions do not
arise. Except in very extra-ordinary cases where projects would be of such
magnitude in relation to the whole economy of the country that local counter-
part funds would really be an important factor in the whole econoIl\Y of the
country, the local currency counterpart of our loans would not have great
importance.
On the other ham, i t is not true that we never exercise any control because [ in the use of the local currency counterpart, if I remember correctly, in
both the Colombian and Chilean loans we have some control of the local
counterpart â€¢. It is, however, quite different from the E.C.A. control.
In the Colombian case our loan is given to an institution which buys
- 2252 -  /d. _
agricultural machinery and sells it on to other people and thereby gets a
certain amount of local currency. There is a provision in the Colombian loan, against which I raised some protest, that they could use that local
currency only for servicing their debt to us. Beyond that there is a
certain general control on c runterpart money, as in the case of the Chilean
loan. So far as I know, they need our consent to use local currency but
we do not look at it in connection with general economic and monetary
policies of the country as E.C.A. does. We just want to know what our
borrower is doing with the money he is getting when he sells goods he
bought with money borrowed from us.
BARANSKI: To come back to the local currency counterpart control, I think it may
provide the criterion how various kinds of loans should be defined or
called. If a firm or institution executing the project is getting the
loan, i.e. it is itself the debtor, that is a specific project loan. If
a Goverrnnent gets a loan and sells equipment to a firm which needs it,
for cash, that is not a specific project loan. Sometimes it can happen then
that local currency counterpart, S6 acquired, is sterilized. Colombian loan
having the provision that local currency obtained from sales of the
agricultural equipment should be held for the purpose of repaying the loan
may be considered as an example. A loan of this kind is a balance of
payments loan, a pure type of a balance of payment loan. Then the local
currency counterpart can be controlled in such a way that it can be released
for local investment purposes. In this case, it is a combination of a
balance of payment loan with a local currency loan given for specific
local programs. It may happen that the counterpart use is allowed for
general purposes of the State and then it is a combination of balance of
payments loan with a simple budgetary loan. These are the various types
of foreign loans which can occur everywhere and of course also in the Bank.
There are four types of loans, according to the application oÂ£ the principle
- 2253 -  n~N: The is a commitment charge only and no interest?
Then when we borrow from the market, we pay 3!%. HOlf is the Bank compensated
for the difference in that charge or is the Bank compensated at all?
. CRENA DE The difference in reality is not so very great, because in the first period, IONGH: the Bank has the money, and can invest it in short-term securities, thereby
earning interest. In the second period the Bank gets the full interest but
the money which is not disbursed carries interest in favor of the borrower,
so the difference for the Bank of the first 5 i:x: months and the rest of the
term of the loan is not so big, but I fully agree with you that when we come
to a period when the Bank will have to finance out of borrowed funds, it
will have to manage very carefully, because margin of i of 1% is extremely
slight.
ONARAN: Thank you.
SYN: If the borrower is a private company, and if this private canpany has to
raise money in the local market, for some reason is excusable to do so,
can pressure be brought on the government which guaranteed the loan?
CRENA DE In the case of Brazilian Light and Traction, that company could prove IONGH: that it would be able to furnish local currency out of their earnings.
We studied that very carefully, because there was no provision that the Government should furnish local currency, and it would be very difficult
for the company to raise money by selling its own funds locally. As the
earnings are substantial local currency could always be found by cutting
dividends. Unless costs reached up tremendously, we think the canpany
will be able to finance its local currency expenditures out of its earnings.
BARANSKI: In the case of Colombia and Mexico, what is the size of the expenditure in
local currency, in relation to the projects?
Can you recall that, Mr. Crena de Iough?
CRENA DE I hesitate to give any figures by heart, but i t is quite important â€¢. Tn the IONGH: construction of electrical projects we have come across cases where local
- 2255 - CRENA DE IONGH : currency amounted to 70% of the total coati. I would not say that was so \vont Id) much in the Mexican case.
CHAIRMAU: I think I can quote the figures on Brazil. The total project was $194
million and our loan was $75, so there was an equivalent of $119 in local
currency. I do not recall the figures for Chile, but I thiru~ it was at
least CIJ% local currency, and in Mexico, I think it was also in the
neighoorhood of 60%. BEYEN: Our discussion reminds me rather of the fugues of Bach, because we develop
two different themes at the sare time in the hope they will together produce
a harmonious sound,and after Mr. Onaran talked about local currency in one
sense I will start again to talk of it in the other sense. I hope that
still somebody will know what sort of local currency we are talking about.
I am talking about what Mr. Bresciani is talking about. I want to add
one thing to Mr. Baranski's remarks; it is of course true, i f we give a
general balance of payments loan or stabilization loans, that in that case
the local currency counterpart would give rise to considerations of general
monetary policies, and I agree with him that there we would find ourselves be in a similar position as E.C.A. I would/rather apprehensive, however,
that we adopt the principle of looking into general monetary consequences
before any general balance of payments loan or stabilization loans are given.
As the situation is now, we give only specific project loans. In the case
of such loans the arising of a local currency counterpart is an accident.
It just depends on whether the borrower prefers to use the goods bought
with the proceeds of our loan himself or whether he sells them. In the
latter case, the real consideration to have some influence on what the
borrower is doing with the local counterpart money is the following: if
a man borrows money from you to buy something, then sells it and gets cash
for it, his creditor will naturally be interested in what he does with the
cash. Let us therefore not confuse the issue. We should be careful not
- 2256 -  BF.YEN I to extend our interest beyond what we are dealing with in a given case. ( It ld) tHtESCIANI: I should like that the question I put be not mis-interpreted. I simply
put the qu.estion whether the Bank exerts scme kind of c antral on expeooi ture
of local currency, but I did not support that control. On the contrary, I
completely agree with Mr. Beyen, it is a very serious question whether we
have to control local expenditure. In the case of E.G.A. I am quite convinced
that it is very important, and also necessary enormous sums being involved,
that E.G.A. exerts certain control. I shall add that, as concerns Italy,
we have experienced some inconveniences. The counterpart funds are blocked
and remain blocked for a long time. As long as they remain blocked there is
deflation; suddenly enormous sums are released and thrown on to the market.
For my part, I also would not support control of our Bank on the use of the
counterpart funds. In any case, the problem ought to be examined in all
its details. As concerning the construction of hydro-electric power stations,
inquiries made in Italy have led to the result that a percentage of foreign
expenditure is somewhere between 5 and 10 percent of the total cost of the
project, so that more than 90% represents expenditure which ought to be
made in local currency. This concerns hydro-electric power p1ants; in steam
power plants the percentage of local, exchange is higher, about 15-20.
In any case it is a very serious problem for a country such as Italy to
take a foreign loan which i t can use only for purchasing foreign goods.
HOPPENOT: I would like to say a few words. The first point is one of language. I do
not think that a too tight line should be drawn between so-called general
purposes am special loans. It is only a good way of express ing ones
thouf11ts. To take a few examples, are the French ships in general, and the
Dutch ships specific? Are the French locomotives general and Indian
locomotives specific? I think the Bank has been very wise not to make that
question one of policy because it has been very difficult to define.
My second point is on the difference of E.G.A. policy am policy of lending
- 2257 -  17.
HOPPENar : institution like the Bank, as to counterpart funds; it is an important 'ont 'd) point for E.C.A. policy first, as Mr. Deyen so ably stated, because of
the importance of the sums involved but also because E.C.A. makes grants
which means that the proceeds of the sale of goods furnished by E.G.A.
are entirely free am stay in the country. A lending institution like the
Bank some day or other gets back its money in interest and amortization
which in fact makes larger sums than the primary cost of the goods
provided for on the loan.
CHANG: While we have the question of local currency, I would like to ask a question
on a matter of policy, and that is that perhaps there is a tb ird kind of
local currency. I remember the Board discussing at one time the urrlesirabilit;)
of granting loans in local currency. I wonder whether the Bank has studied
the question further, am whether the Financial Policy Cormnittee has gone
into the matter further.
CHAIRMAN: We have had problems up, and you know the question of establishing
"extraordinary ciryumstarees" is a rather difficult one. It is important
the circumstances be considered and discussed very broadly, but we are
bound by the restrictions in the Articles that you have to establish
extraordinary circumstances. We have not yet founi conditions where we felt
that this existed.
CHANG: In other words, there has been no decision reached as to a definite policy
of the Bank.
CHAIRMAN: The policy of the Bank is laid down in the Articles, and we can only lend
local currency under extraordinary circumstances. The policy ww1d be,
i f we see a case that rates that kind of extraordinary circumstances, then
we should look at it â€¢
.t.RANSKl : We have discussed this matter a1 ready; the memoramum prepared by the
Financial Policy Committee am approved by the Board concerning this policy
is so far I understand still ruling our actions.  HS.
r,HAIRMAN : Thank you; this discussion has been helpful.
I would like to ask Mr. Boar to report briefly on the loan situation.
HOAR: I have just two matters which I thought worth mentioning.
The first concerns EL SALVADOR. As the Executive Directors are aware, we
had thought during the last few weeks that we would be able to move very
quickly with El Salvador and, in preparation for that, we had already
furnished the Executive Directors with the economic report on the country,
the report on the Rio Lempa project, draft Loan and Guarantee Agreements,
and even a draft of the President's recoImBendations. Indeed, at the time
Mr. Iliff made his last report, it was expected that the loan proposal would
very quickly be submitted to the Executive Directors for their final
consideration. Since then, however, we have heard we shall not be able
to proceed quite as quickly as we had hoped.
We have been informed from El Salvador that the Council of Government and
the Cabinet have agreed on the basic conditions of the loan and have approved
in principle the draft agreeroonts. In view, however, of the magnitude of
the transaction in relation to the size of the country, the Government is
anxious to have the opinion of as broad a cross-section of the public and
buSiness community as pOSSible, not in respect to the principle of the
project but on the question of the commitments' the Government is expected
to make on behalf of the people of El salvador. They have set up an A.d
Hoc Committee for the purpose of studying the draft Loan and Guarantee
Agreeroonts aDi of advising the Government on them. This Committee will
be uDier the chairmanship of the Undersecretary of Economy and will consist
of the President of the Rio Lempa Conmlission, the President of the Court
of Accounts and six other members who will be selected by the lfinister of
Economy including two lawyers, one civil engineer and three persons chosen
from banking and busioos8.
BARANSKI a Will there be also representatives of the private electric power plants in
Salvador?  19.
HOAR: I understand not.
The work of the Committee is expected to take three to four weeks so that,
including any discussion that may arise from their recommendations, it
looks as though we shall not be able to lay the loan before you before
the end of November or the beginning of December.
CHAIRMAN : I think it is rather interesting to see a country take so seriously the
question of incurring any indebtedness.
HOAR: It is clear that it is not a matter of procrastination, but should be taken
as evidence of the seriousness with which they regard this problem and the
acceptance of the obligations.
As you will be aware from Mr. nUf's last report, Mr. Consolo of the Loan
Department and Mr. Waterston of the Economic Department are due to leave
today for a visit to Nicaragua. On his way back, Mr. Consolo is to call in
in El Salvador to get an impression of the progress of the forementioned
Committee and to discuss aI\Y points that may have arisen in the course of
this work. will In the circumstances, we have asked Mr. Tucker, whom you/remember was
scheduled to visit El Salvador in order to advise on the local bond issue,
to postpone his visit until after the signing of the Agreements.
The other point which I would mention is that we are plarming to send a
Bank mission to Asia at the end of the year, visiting the Philippines,
Thailand aIJi India, probably in that order.
To take the case of the PHILIPPINES, the Executive Directors will remember
that aoout a year ago the Bank wrote to the Philippine Goverrunent giving
the Bank's views on fiscal and economic measures that appeared to be
necessary to support the Philippine development program and saying that,
in reliance upon the Philippine statement of their intention to proceed
with necessary measures, the Bank would be willing to enter into negotiations
for a loan of $15 million for two hydro-electric projects on the Agmo River, in the island of Luzon. - 2260 -  LV.
HOAR: The technical report on the first of these projects has just been received. ( t 'd) The Philippine National Power Commission let us have this report last Bank's week and it is now being studied by the/technical staff.. In the meantime,
however, the reports ~TIich have reached the Bank of financial and economic
developments in the Philippines have been disquieting. In the circ~tances,
the President of the Bank has informed Mr. Cuaderno and the Philippine
Ambassador, in the course of the last week, that the Bank wished to have
another look at the situation on the ~ ot and, accordingly, we are planning
to send a mission at the beginning of December. We cannot send it earlier
because the Philippines are going through the turmoil of preparing for
the Presidential election and we will wait until things simmer dOÂ¥fl a bit.
However, we do hope to have an economic and financial report available
shortly after Christmas.
Then to THAILAND. I believe Mr. Iliff has reported to you that the Thais
have laid before us statements of projects in which they would like the
Bank to be interested, involving a foreign exchange expenditure of $33 million for railways and $22 million for irrigation, drainage, power and
navigation on the Chao Phya River. In that connection, we shall of course,
need to send our usual comprehensive mission.
Then with INDIA. There are two loans already made, as we all know, the
railways loan and the Kana Grass loan, and we are actively working on the
third, the Bokaro Thermal Station as part of the namodar Valley scheme.
These pro j ects are not, of course, all those th e Indian Government would
like the Bank to finance am far from being a complete range of development.
The Bank, of course, is interested in how the development scheIIe3 am being regard to the handled with/priorities of development and/provision of finance. Then
there is the question of the effect of the devaluation of the pound and
the lr:Klian rupee. With all of these things in consideration, we felt we
wruld like to have a mission re\'isit India and discuss the natters with
- 2261 -  HOAR: those responsible. The Indian Government has informed us that they have ( t'd) no objection. We shall have one mission to visit all three countries,to
be led by Mr. Rucinski of the Loan Department, who accompanied me on my
trip to India, and who will be accompanied by Dr. Basch of the Economic
Department. There will be added to the mission such experts in economics
and technical problems as may seem appropriate. There is one other factor
and that is that the Fund are sending a mission which is circumnavigating
the globe and is go ing to visit, among others, both India and tbe Philippines.
I am hoping to have a talk about that with Mr. Overby this afternoon in order
to see the timing of these things and make what arrangements we can to see
that there is a minimum of inconvenience to the countries.
CHAIRJ.AAN : Any questions'l
HOOKER: May I ask about Uruguay.
lli: Uruguay is moving along very rapidly and satisfactorily. I cannot give you
a date. The Staff Loan Committee is meeting this afternoon.
HOOKER: Fundamentally we are awaiting Uruguay's action which I understand is
causing the delay.
CJ-I..AIRMAN: We were awaiting appointment of a negotiator.
HOAR: It is going ahead.
CHAIRMAN: I have one or two matters I wculd like to mention.
You Will recall that scmetime ago Mr. Black referred the problem in certain _
countries in oormection with use of the 18% currencies for administrative
expenses when we send missions to those oountries. It applies in those
countries mere the rate of exchange used in making' subscriptions does not
properly reflect the real buying power of the currency in the country.
were the Bank to use a member's currency for such expenses at the official
rate of exchange and the costs are very high in relation to that, the
expenses to the Bank are disprOpuDtionate.
Just to use an extreme illustration, let us say, suppose it is paid in at the rate of one unit of local currency to the dollar am the actual true
foreign exchange value reflects about five units to the dollar, a mission that we would expect to cost $1,000 would cost $5,000 and thus inflate
the Bank's expenses.
This problem arose some time ago and, in the case of China, France, Italy,
Mexico and Poland, we made arrangements which enabla:l us to meet this
situation. In those cases what was done "as that the member would purchase
the small amounts of their 18% currency with dollars at the normal rate of
exchange and then permit the Bank to sell those dollars at the free market
or some other appropriate rate. We would like to make similar arrangements
with other member countries whenever we find that we have need for such
disbursements and where the subscription rate differs with the actual rate
of exchange.
At the time of the Fourth Annual Meeting, the President requested the
Governors of Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Ecuador, Lebanon,
Paraguay and Uruguay to discuss this matter. All the Governors, except
those of Costa Rica and Uruguay attended, partiCipated in the discussion
and the following day we sent memoranda to all Governors of the countries
mentioned. All those attending the discussion indicated their willingness
to make the necessary arrangements.
However, to date we have had no formal advice from any of these countries
except Colombia, whose communication arrived yesterday' fran Mr. Toro, but
we have not had an opportunity to examine it. I would like the Executive
Directors who represent the countries mentioned to follow up this matter.
We would greatly appreciate it i f you would communicate with these
respective Governments and ask i f they will move ahead with malting the
arrangements which they have irrlicated willingness to work out.
In the future there may be other countries where this situation arises
am in this event we would take it up at this time. We would greatly  L.J.
CHAIRllAN: appreciate it i f you gentlemen concerned would assist us in this matter by ')nt 'd) following up and requesting some action.
BARREDA- MOLLER: May I ask you to say again ~at countries you have dealt with.
CHAIRMAN: The countries we have dealt with already are China, France, Italy, Mexico
and Poland.
BARREDA- MOLLER: And the conversations we have had in the last meeting of the Governors.
CHAIRMAN: Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Ecuador, Lebanon, Paraguay and Uruguay.
BARREDA- MOLLER: Thank you very much.
BARANSKI: One question, Mr. Chairman. Is it necessary to have such an arrangement
with Mexico now, because they have devalued?
CHAIRMAN : They made that arrangement at the time when such a situation existed.
Mexico went back to the time before their devaluation â€¢
..RANSKI: Mexico is now after devaluation and certainly has supplemented local currency
paid in.
CHAIRMAN: This situation does not arise in connection with Mexico.
BEYEN: Have they done it?
CRENA DE IONGH: Mexico has not.
CHAIRMAN: What are we doing in regard to that?
CRENA DE Of all the countries that have devalued, only Canada and Great Britain are IONGH: at present putting up more treasury bills.
CHAIRMAN: Yes, but Mexico's devaluation occurred last summer.
CRENA DE lIexico paid up promptly after that devaluation. I do not know wnether IONGH I at present the tourist rate differs from the official rate.
BEYEN: That does not arise in Uexico. There is no tourist rate.
Mr. Chairman, I am happy to state that we have fou.n:i a fourth kim of local
currency. (Laughter)
ONARAN: May I ask about the case of Lebanon? CHAIRMAN: Lebanon is one of the cases where we requested that arrangements be made.
Now these are the countries where we have had people or we are trying to
send people in the near future. It only arises when we have need for local
expenditures but i f we wait until we send people there, there is not time
to work arrangements out. We would like, therefore, to get the principle
established, and in these member countries, we would appreciate help.
There is one other matter I would like to explain for information of the
Directors. We have had a few suggestions that it would be helpful i f we
could make arrangements for scme responsible public employees from some of
the umer-<ieveloped countries to spend some time in the Bank, and other
agencies in this country, observing administration and operating practices
and policies. It may be in the field of budgeting, it may be in the field
of tax administration, or aqy other fields in which it might be helpful for
some responsible people of fairly senior rank to spend some time observing
practices in this country. We have been discussing it, and arrived at an
experimental plan to try. We thought of bringing over a small number of
such people, ani give them the opportunity to work out a program whereby
they could get experience and observe some good administrative and
operating practices in public organizations. It might be in the Federal
('.overnment and perhaps more usefully in sOOte of the small governmental
State, Municipal or public authorities. We would like to um ertake this
program by using the contacts our missions have, am try to pick out two
or three men and try this thing out. Our thought is that we would be
prepared to pay transportation expenses am subsistence. They would remain
on their Government payroll, am we would not bring them over for employment
in the Bank, but that they would return to their positions and be able to
carry back the benefit of their experience.
CHANG: HOlf long would they be here?
- 2265 - (:}{A IRMAN: 1 do not know. It might vary, but it would be scmewhere between three and )nt Id) six months, depending on the problem and on the particular individual.
We think it should be long enough [or the man to get some real knowledge
and information that he can go back and cite. As I say, this is something
we have to experiment with, and therefore, we thought the best way to do
it is just quietly, without any announcement, to see if we can pick out
two or three men and try it out. Based on that experience, we could determine
whether a regular established program is worth carrying forward, how many
people we can handle, and how to do it.. We would prefer you do not pass this
word outside the Bank as i f it gets around we are afraid we shall get such a
number of applicants before we know enough to handle it. We did want the
Directors to know about this experiroont, and we would be very glad to have
any comments or advice that any of you might have as to how to set this
program up. Mr. Howell has been giving a good deal of attention to this for a number of months, and has consulted with a number of people in other
organizations that are doing similar work in the United States. The cost
for this would. be small. OUr observation has been that in a number of
countries the administrative problems are quite important and i f we could,
through this means, be effective in helping to train a small group of
people over a period of years, it may be a real contribution by the Bank.
We think it would be practical only to provide for people coming to the
United States at this time, but as we get experience it may be p,ossible
and seem advisable to provide for them getting training in other countries.
We would like to start on this program and try it out, and after we have
had a little experience, then review that experience and discuss with you
whether or not the program is worth continuing and expaOOing, and the
means by which you think it can be effectively carried out.
HOPPENar: I feel it is quite a good project, and the Bank should do all it can to
have people come here am learn the ways not only of the Bank, but of the
- 2266 -  26.
!-J(IPPEHOT : United States, and in time, as you say, of other countries. I can only mt'd) approve such a program as you have set forth to us.
BARANSKI: I will say here what corresponds roughly to what I said to the International
Civil Service Advisory Connnittee of the United Nations, of which I am a
member, when United Nations started a ~milar action. I told them, that
there is a certain danger in having people from the under-developed
countries come to highly developed centera to see how they work and then
going back and simply copying the methods. Wonderful stories can happen
after. I would say only from my own experience, that after the First
World War, we had many such visits am appointments of American "managerial
engineersll in some badly organized enterprises in Poland, but the results
of their advices were immediately existent; a jump-up of the cost of the
enterprise, because cheap methods were simply replaced by expensive methods,
and nothing happened to the organization which was as bad as before. It
is necessary to have first for this purpose, very intelligent people, so
that they could observe but not slavishly copy from their observation,
and also very intelligent advice to them as to what is possible to adapt
in their awn countries, and what is not possible. In a country like the which United States, there are many big organizations and working methods/are
adapted to these big organizations. Nothing could be so wrong as to train
these people in these methods for adapting them to small organizations. CHAIRllAN: That is perfectly true, am we think that in many cases, most valuable
experience will be in some of the smaller units of government departments.
I am not quite sure whether the Government in the United States is so good
that you can say it is, a Council of perfection. In the future, it might
well be that experience in some smaller countries would be useful as well,
but we do not think we can start this thing except here, where we can
have close observation.
BRESCIANI: In connection with wnat Mr. Baranski said, I would like to ask, according
- 2261 - ~qr:SCIANI : to what concept will these people come here - young people, or high Jontld) officials? CHAIRMAN: Our thought is we would like to get people sufficiently senior that they
could go back to their countries and exercise influence. They are a
different cut of people Ulan the trainees that we have. But there again,
we have to try it out, and that is the reason we do not want to publicly
launch this thing until it has had trial runs.
BRESCIANI: It would be as well to have people who are able to give a counterpart for
what the Bank does for them. As far as I can see, the problem of under-
developed countries has become a central problem in the Bank, and these
people could give us same advice on how we could give them help, and
what would be the consequences of tilat.
CHAIRMAN: It would be very useful. :JffiU: You say the choice would be made by tile Bank's missions aborad, and I wonder
if it would not be a better idea to get men through the Governments, as
they are likely to know more about it. CHAIRMAN: The reason is tilat, if we suggest to the Governments, we may have fifty
to seventy-five applicants. What we thought tilat we would do would be
to have people in the miss ions in the field, 'Who will have met a number of
these people, see someone they thought suitable, and then they would talk
about it informally with the Government, and say "How about a man like thisll7
We are afraid to put out any general announcement in case we get over-
whelmed before we are better prepared. It will be done in consultation
with tile Governments, but on the ground, quietly and informa.lly.
ONARAN: Does the scheme include municipal administration in this country1 CHAIRMAN: We think we can make arrangements with some of our cities; some have very
good administration and sane very bad.
- 2268 - ONARAN: This is as important as public administration for under-developed countries,
because they are more backHard in their administration. I agree with Mr.
I3aranski there is a danger that unless they are very intelligent when they
go back they may try to apply all they have seen here.
CHAIRMAN: That is important. Vie will go ahead on this in a quiet way, and see how
it works.
There is just one other announcement I would like to make. I would like
to invite attention to a circular which was sent out over the Signature of
the President, dated October 20, regarding the Community Chest in Washington.
We have in the past contributed generously to the Comnninity Chest, and we
feel it is the appropriate thing. We try very carefully to avoid appeals
for contributions in the Bank, but this is something that covers all the
chari ties in this community in which we all now live, am as in the past,
representatives of the Bank's staff will go through the building am we
hope that eve~one will listen to their story and then, if you feel so
inclined, make such contribution you feel appropriate. There is no
pressure on anybody, but we feel that we who are now living in Washington
should support public cOlilltlmity services. Mr. Black will not be back until
Friday, so i f it is satisfactory to the Directors, I would suggest that
we do not fix the date of the next meeting until he gets back. I f there
is nothing up for Tuesday, then it may be later in the week, and an
announcement will be made.
ADJOURNED AT 11:50 A.M.
